idioms.title: A blessing in disguise
idioms.description: A good thing that seemed bad at first.
examples: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise — it led me to a better opportunity.
Missing the flight turned out to be a blessing in disguise.

idioms.title: Beat around the bush
idioms.description: Avoid saying what you really mean.
examples: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what happened.
He kept beating around the bush instead of giving a direct answer.

idioms.title: Hit the sack
examples: I'm really tired, I think I'll hit the sack.
After the long day, she hit the sack early.

idioms.title: Under the weather
examples: I'm feeling a bit under the weather today.
He didn’t come to work because he was under the weather.

idioms.title: Let the cat out of the bag
examples: She let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party.
He accidentally let the cat out of the bag.

idioms.title: Cutting corners
idioms.description: Doing something poorly or cheaply to save time or money.
examples: The builder was cutting corners and now the roof is leaking.
Don't cut corners on this project — do it properly.

idioms.title: Bite the bullet
idioms.description: To endure a painful or unpleasant situation that is unavoidable.
examples: I hate going to the dentist, but I'll just have to bite the bullet.
She decided to bite the bullet and start her own business.

idioms.title: Bite off more than he can chew
idioms.description: To take on more responsibility than one can manage.
examples: He bit off more than he could chew by accepting two jobs at once.
Don't bite off more than you can chew — focus on one task at a time.

idioms.title: Break the ice
idioms.description: To initiate conversation in a social setting to reduce tension or awkwardness.
examples: He told a joke to break the ice at the meeting.
It's always hard to break the ice at a new job.

idioms.title: Speak of the devil
idioms.description: Said when someone mentioned appears unexpectedly.
examples: Speak of the devil — we were just talking about you!
Oh look, speak of the devil — there's John.

idioms.title: Cost an arm and a leg
examples: That new car cost me an arm and a leg.
This designer bag costs an arm and a leg!

idioms.title: Once in a blue moon
examples: He only visits his hometown once in a blue moon.
I eat junk food only once in a blue moon.

idioms.title: On the same page
idioms.description: To agree or have the same understanding about something.
examples: Before we start, I want to make sure we're on the same page.
The team is finally on the same page about the project goals.

idioms.title: Pull someone's leg
examples: Relax, I was just pulling your leg!
He said he won the lottery, but he was just pulling my leg.
